Early Latin Literature. The beginning of 'Latin Litera- ture cannot be dated from an epoch earlier than the middle of the third century B.c. While Rome was gradually working her way to undisputed rule in Italy, while the Roman type of character was being formed, and the vigour os Roman na- tionality reaching its highest point, no literature was produced which posterity thought worthy of preservation, The Roman genius was unimaginative. lts practical character was w-holly opposed to literary creation, and especially to that poetical form of it, in which nations generally make their early attempts at expression. No people, which belongs to history, has passed through a more stirring youth than the Romans; yet, if we limit our view to the period during which Roman genius received no promptings lrom without, we find that no people has'left so meagre an intellectual monument of its dangers, its sufferingS, and its triumphs
